new.haxe_doc: * * @param r an Int value between 0 and 255 for the red channel * @param g an Int value between 0 and 255 for the green channel * @param b an Int value between 0 and 255 for the blue channel

length.haxe_doc: The number of characters in the String.

toUpperCase.haxe_doc: Returns an String where all characters have been uppercased.

toLowerCase.haxe_doc: Returns an String where all characters have been lowercased.

charAt.haxe_doc: Returns the character at the given position. Returns the empty String if outside of String bounds.

charCodeAt.haxe_doc: Returns the character code at the given position. Returns [null] if outside of String bounds.

indexOf.haxe_doc: Returns the index of first occurence of [value] Returns [1-1] if [value] is not found. The optional [startIndex] parameter allows you to specify at which character to start searching. The position returned is still relative to the beginning of the string.

lastIndexOf.haxe_doc: Similar to [indexOf] but returns the latest index.

split.haxe_doc: Split the string using the specified delimiter.

substr.haxe_doc: Returns a part of the String, taking [len] characters starting from [pos]. If [len] is not specified, it takes all the remaining characters.

new.haxe_doc: Creates a copy from a given String.

length.haxe_doc: The number of elements in this list.

add.haxe_doc: Add an element at the end of the list.

push.haxe_doc: Push an element at the beginning of the list.

first.haxe_doc: Returns the first element of the list, or null if the list is empty.

last.haxe_doc: Returns the last element of the list, or null if the list is empty.

pop.haxe_doc: Removes the first element of the list and returns it or simply returns null if the list is empty.

isEmpty.haxe_doc: Tells if a list is empty.

remove.haxe_doc: Remove the first element that is [== v] from the list. Returns [true] if an element was removed, [false] otherwise.

iterator.haxe_doc: Returns an iterator on the elements of the list.

toString.haxe_doc: Returns a displayable representation of the String.

join.haxe_doc: Join the element of the list by using the separator [sep].

filter.haxe_doc: Returns a list filtered with [f]. The returned list will contain all elements [x] for which [f(x) = true].

map.haxe_doc: Returns a new list where all elements have been converted by the function [f].

class.haxe_doc: A linked-list of elements. The list is composed of two-elements arrays that are chained together. It's optimized so that adding or removing an element doesn't imply to copy the whole array content everytime.

enum.haxe_doc: The standard Void type. Only [null] values can be of the type [Void].

class.haxe_doc: The standard Float type, this is a double-precision IEEE 64bit float.
The standard Int type. Its precision depends on the platform.

typedef.haxe_doc: [Null] can be useful in two cases. In order to document some methods that accepts or can return a [null] value, or for the Flash9 compiler and AS3 generator to distinguish between base values that can be null and others that can't.

enum.haxe_doc: The standard Boolean type is represented as an enum with two choices.

class.haxe_doc: Dynamic is an internal compiler type which has special behavior. See the haXe language reference for more informations.

typedef.haxe_doc: An Iterator is a structure that permits to list a given container values. It can be used by your own data structures. See the haXe documentation for more informations.
An Iterable is a data structure which has an iterator() method. See [Lambda] for generic functions on iterable structures.

class.haxe_doc: ArrayAccess is used to indicate a class that can be accessed using brackets. The type parameter represent the type of the elements stored.

match.haxe_doc: Tells if the regular expression matches the String. Updates the internal state accordingly.

matched.haxe_doc: Returns a matched group or throw an expection if there is no such group. If [n = 0], the whole matched substring is returned.

matchedLeft.haxe_doc: Returns the part of the string that was as the left of of the matched substring.

matchedRight.haxe_doc: Returns the part of the string that was at the right of of the matched substring.

matchedPos.haxe_doc: Returns the position of the matched substring within the original matched string.

split.haxe_doc: Split a string by using the regular expression to match the separators.

replace.haxe_doc: Replaces a pattern by another string. The [by] format can contains [$1] to [$9] that will correspond to groups matched while replacing. [$$] means the [$] character.

customReplace.haxe_doc: For each occurence of the pattern in the string [s], the function [f] is called and can return the string that needs to be replaced. All occurences are matched anyway, and setting the [g] flag might cause some incorrect behavior on some platforms.

new.haxe_doc: Creates a new regular expression with pattern [r] and options [opt].

class.haxe_doc: Regular expressions are a way to find regular patterns into Strings. Have a look at the tutorial on haXe website to learn how to use them.

compare.haxe_doc: * @todo add compare over comparison method for custom classes

new.haxe_doc: * Construct a Cmyk Color. * @param cyan Float bewteen 0 and 1 * @param magenta Float bewteen 0 and 1 * @param yellow Float bewteen 0 and 1 * @param black Float bewteen 0 and 1

class.haxe_doc: An abstract type that represents a Class. See [Type] for the haXe Reflection API.

hasField.haxe_doc: Tells if an object has a field set. This doesn't take into account the object prototype (class methods).

field.haxe_doc: Returns the field of an object, or null if [o] is not an object or doesn't have this field.

callMethod.haxe_doc: Call a method with the given object and arguments.

fields.haxe_doc: Returns the list of fields of an object, excluding its prototype (class methods).

isFunction.haxe_doc: Tells if a value is a function or not.

compare.haxe_doc: Generic comparison function, does not work for methods, see [compareMethods]

compareMethods.haxe_doc: Compare two methods closures. Returns true if it's the same method of the same instance.

isObject.haxe_doc: Tells if a value is an object or not.

copy.haxe_doc: Make a copy of the fields of an object.

makeVarArgs.haxe_doc: Transform a function taking an array of arguments into a function that can be called with any number of arguments.

class.haxe_doc: The Reflect API is a way to manipulate values dynamicly through an abstract interface in an untyped manner. Use with care.

hasNext.haxe_doc: Returns true if the iterator has other items, false otherwise.

next.haxe_doc: Moves to the next item of the iterator.

new.haxe_doc: Iterate from [min] (inclusive) to [max] (exclusive). If [max <= min], the iterator will not act as a countdown.

class.haxe_doc: Integer iterator. Used for interval implementation.
This class defines mathematical functions and constants.

getClass.haxe_doc: Returns the class of a value or [null] if this value is not a Class instance.

getEnum.haxe_doc: Returns the enum of a value or [null] if this value is not an Enum instance.

getSuperClass.haxe_doc: Returns the super-class of a class, or null if no super class.

getClassName.haxe_doc: Returns the complete name of a class.

getEnumName.haxe_doc: Returns the complete name of an enum.

resolveClass.haxe_doc: Evaluates a class from a name. The class must have been compiled to be accessible.

resolveEnum.haxe_doc: Evaluates an enum from a name. The enum must have been compiled to be accessible.

createInstance.haxe_doc: Creates an instance of the given class with the list of constructor arguments.

createEmptyInstance.haxe_doc: Similar to [Reflect.createInstance] excepts that the constructor is not called. This enables you to create an instance without any side-effect.

createEnum.haxe_doc: Create an instance of an enum by using a constructor name and parameters.

createEnumIndex.haxe_doc: Create an instance of an enum by using a constructor index and parameters.

getInstanceFields.haxe_doc: Returns the list of instance fields.

getClassFields.haxe_doc: Returns the list of a class static fields.

getEnumConstructs.haxe_doc: Returns all the available constructor names for an enum.

typeof.haxe_doc: Returns the runtime type of a value.

enumEq.haxe_doc: Recursively compare two enums constructors and parameters.

enumConstructor.haxe_doc: Returns the constructor of an enum

enumParameters.haxe_doc: Returns the parameters of an enum

enumIndex.haxe_doc: Returns the index of the constructor of an enum

class.haxe_doc: The haXe Reflection API enables you to retreive informations about any value, Classes and Enums at runtime.

set.haxe_doc: Set a value for the given key.

get.haxe_doc: Get a value for the given key.

exists.haxe_doc: Tells if a value exists for the given key. In particular, it's useful to tells if a key has a [null] value versus no value.

remove.haxe_doc: Removes a hashtable entry. Returns [true] if there was such entry.

keys.haxe_doc: Returns an iterator of all keys in the hashtable.

iterator.haxe_doc: Returns an iterator of all values in the hashtable.

toString.haxe_doc: Returns an displayable representation of the hashtable content.

class.haxe_doc: Hashtable over a set of elements, using [Int] as keys. On Flash and Javascript, the underlying structure is an Object.

set.haxe_doc: Set a value for the given key.

get.haxe_doc: Get a value for the given key.

exists.haxe_doc: Tells if a value exists for the given key. In particular, it's useful to tells if a key has a [null] value versus no value.

remove.haxe_doc: Removes a hashtable entry. Returns [true] if there was such entry.

keys.haxe_doc: Returns an iterator of all keys in the hashtable.

iterator.haxe_doc: Returns an iterator of all values in the hashtable.

toString.haxe_doc: Returns an displayable representation of the hashtable content.

class.haxe_doc: Hashtable over a set of elements, using [String] as keys. Other kind of keys are not possible on all platforms since they can't always be implemented efficiently.

format.haxe_doc:
* Take a string pattern and replaces the placeholders with the value contained in values. * The culture parameter is needed for proper localization of numeric and date values. * Placeholders follows this schema: 
{pos[:format][,param]*}
* pos is the position in the array * format is a string sequence that identifies a specific value format (see below) * param is one or more optional parameters specific to certain format values. * * 
Numeric Formats
---------------
D (default) Decimal format. The default number of decimals is set by culture. This value can overriden
            using the length parameter.
I           Integer format.
C           Currency format. The default number of decimals is set by culture. This value can overriden
            using the length parameter. The symbol can be overridden appending a string value after C
			Ei. "{0:C,3,USD}" will print something like "USD2.000" instead of "$2.00"
P           Percent format.
M           Permille format.

Date Formats
---------------
D (default) Date format.
DS          Short Date format.
DST         Short date / long time format.
DSTS        Short date / short time format.
DT          Long date / long time format.
DTS         Long date / short time format.
Y           Year format.
YM          Year Month format.
M           Month format.
MN          Month name format.
MS          Short Month name format.
MD          Month Day format.
WD          Week day format.
WDN         Week day name format.
WDS         Short week day name format.
R           RFC Date format.
DT          Date Time format.
U           Universal format.
S           Sortable format.
T           Time format.
TS          Short Time format.
C			Custom, second parameter is the format as described in FormatDate

Boolean Formats
---------------
B			Normal bool (true, false)
N			Numeric representation (1, 0)
R			Replace values with first parameter for true and second for false

String Formats
---------------
S			Normal text.
T           Truncate. First parameter is the length to trim, second is the ellipsis
			(optional parameter, defaults to '...')
PL          Pad left. First parameter is the length, second is filling char
			(optional parameter, defaults to ' ')
PR          Pad right. First parameter is the length, second is filling char
			(optional parameter, defaults to ' ')

List Formats
---------------
J           Joins the elements of the list.
			The first parameter is the format for individual items
			The second parameter is what is shown when the list is empty (defaults to '[]')
			The third is the separator.
            The fourth is the maximum number of values to show (default to nolimit).
			The fifth parameter the ellipsis for not included values (defaults to '...'),
C			Counts the elements in the list
			
TODO:
List Formats
---------------
C           Concats the elements of the list

Other things to do. Nested placeholders

ucwordsws.haxe_doc: * Like ucwords but uses only white spaces as boundaries * @param value * @return

humanize.haxe_doc: * Replaces undescores with space, finds UC characters, turns them into LC and prepends them with a space. * More than one UC in sequence is left untouched.

add.haxe_doc: Adds the representation of any value to the string buffer.

addSub.haxe_doc: Adds a part of a string to the string buffer.

addChar.haxe_doc: Adds a character to the string buffer.

toString.haxe_doc: Returns the content of the string buffer. The buffer is not emptied by this operation.

class.haxe_doc: A String buffer is an efficient way to build a big string by appending small elements together.

map.haxe_doc: Creates a new [Iterable] by appling the function 'f' to all elements of the iterator 'it'.

mapi.haxe_doc: Similar to [map], but also pass an index for each item iterated.

has.haxe_doc: Tells if the element is part of an iterable. The comparison is made using the [==] operator. Optionally you can pass as a third parameter a function that performs the comparison. That function must take as arguments the two items to compare and returns a boolean value.

exists.haxe_doc: Tells if at least one element of the iterable is found by using the specific function.

foreach.haxe_doc: Tells if all elements of the iterable have the specified property defined by [f].

iter.haxe_doc: Call the function 'f' on all elements of the [Iterable] 'it'.

filter.haxe_doc: Return the list of elements matching the function 'f'

count.haxe_doc: Count the number of elements in an [Iterable] having [pred] returning true.

empty.haxe_doc: Tells if an iterable does not contain any element.

indexOf.haxe_doc: Returns the index of the item in the given Iterable, depending on the order of the Iterator. Returns -1 if the item was not found.

concat.haxe_doc: Returns a list containing all items of 'a' followed by all items of 'b'

class.haxe_doc: The [Lambda] class is a collection of functional methods in order to use functional-style programming with haXe.

format.haxe_doc:
* Returns a formatted date according to the passed pattern and culture. The pattern * paramter accepts the following modifiers. * 
    description                                                   example
===========================================================================
%a	The abbreviated weekday name according to the current locale. Wed
%A	The full weekday name according to the current locale.	      Wednesday
%b	The abbreviated month name according to the current locale.	  Jan
%B	The full month name according to the current locale.	      January
%c	The preferred date and time representation for the current locale.
%C	The century number (year/100) as a 2-digit integer.	          19
%d	The day of the month as a decimal number (range 01 to 31).	  07
%D	Equivalent to %m/%d/%y. (This is the USA date format.         06/25/04
    In many countries %d/%m/%y is the standard date format.
    Thus, in an international context, both of these formats are
    ambiguous and should be avoided.)
%e	Like %d, the day of the month as a decimal number, but a      7
    leading zero may be replaced by a leadingspace.
%G	The ISO 8601 year with century as a decimal number. The       2004
    4-digit year corresponding to the ISO week number (see %V).
    This has the same format and value as %y, except that if the
    ISO week number belongs to the previous or next year, that
    year is used instead.
%g	Like %G, but without century, i.e., with a 2-digit year       04
    (00-99).
%h	Equivalent to %b.	                                          Jan
%H	The hour as a decimal number using a 24-hour clock            22
    (range 00 to 23).
%I	The hour as a decimal number using a 12-hour clock            07
    (range 01 to 12).
%j	The day of the year as a decimal number (range 001 to 366).   008
%k	The hour (24-hour clock) as a decimal number (range 0 to 23); 7
    single-digits are optionally prefixed by leadingspace.
    (See also %H.)
%l	The hour (12-hour clock) as a decimal number (range 1 to 12); 7
    single-digits are optionally prefixed by leadingspace.
    (See also %I.)
%m	The month as a decimal number (range 01 to 12).	              04
%M	The minute as a decimal number (range 00 to 59).              08
%n	A newline character.
%p	Either 'AM' or 'PM' according to the given time value, or the AM
    corresponding strings for the current locale. Noon is treated
    as 'pm' and midnight as 'am'.
%P	Like %p but in lowercase: 'am' or 'pm' or a corresponding     AM
    string for the current locale.
%r	The time in a.m. or p.m. notation. In the POSIX locale this   07:08:09 am
    is equivalent to '%I:%M:%S %p'.
%R	The time in 24-hour notation (%H:%M). For a version including 07:08
    the seconds, see %T below.
%s	The number of seconds since the Epoch, i.e., since            1099928130
    1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.
%S	The second as a decimal number (range 00 to 61). the upper    07
    level of the range 61 rather than 59 to allow for the
    occasional leap second and even more occasional double leap
    second.
%t	A tab character.
%T	The time in 24-hour notation (%H:%M:%S).                      17:08:09
%u	The day of the week as a decimal, range 1 to 7, Monday
    being 1. See also %w.
%U	The week number of the current year as a decimal number,      26
    range 00 to 53, starting with the first Sunday as the first
    day of week 01. See also %V and %W.
%V	The ISO 8601:1988 week number of the current year as a        26
    decimal number, range 01 to 53, where week 1 is the first
    week that has at least 4 days in the current year, and with
    Monday as the first day of the week. See also %U and %W.
%w	The day of the week as a decimal, range 0 to 6, Sunday being
    0. See also %u.
%W	The week number of the current year as a decimal number,
    range 00 to 53, starting with the first Monday as the first
    day of week 01.
%x	The preferred date representation for the current locale
    without the time.
%X	The preferred time representation for the current locale
    without the date.
%y	The year as a decimal number without a century                04
    (range 00 to 99).
%Y	The year as a decimal number including the century.           2004
%z	The time-zone as hour offset from GMT. Required to emit       -2
    RFC822-conformant dates (using "%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S %z").
%Z	The time zone or name or abbreviation.                        GMT
%%	A literal '%' character.                                      %

customs for missing features
%f  The month. Single-digit months may be prefixed by             6
    leadingspace.
%i  The minute. Single-digit minutes may be prefixed by           8
    leadingspace.
%q  The second. Single-digit seconds may be prefixed by           9
    leadingspace.

class.haxe_doc: An abstract type that represents an Enum. See [Type] for the haXe Reflection API.

digits.haxe_doc: * Transforms a string of digit from the international format (0...9) to the locale format. * Be sure to include only characters in the 0...9 range.

addIf.haxe_doc: * push the value into the array and return the array itself only if the condition * evaluates to true.

add.haxe_doc: * push the value into the array and return the array itself

delete.haxe_doc: * removes the value from the array and return the array itself

filter.haxe_doc: * creates a new array filtered by the 'f' function

concat.haxe_doc: Returns a new Array by appending [a] to [this].

join.haxe_doc: Returns a representation of an array with [sep] for separating each element.

pop.haxe_doc: Removes the last element of the array and returns it.

push.haxe_doc: Adds the element [x] at the end of the array.

reverse.haxe_doc: Reverse the order of elements of the Array.

shift.haxe_doc: Removes the first element and returns it.

slice.haxe_doc: Copies the range of the array starting at [pos] up to, but not including, [end]. Both [pos] and [end] can be negative to count from the end: -1 is the last item in the array.

sort.haxe_doc: Sort the Array according to the comparison function [f]. [f(x,y)] should return [0] if [x == y], [>0] if [x > y] and [<0] if [x < y].

splice.haxe_doc: Removes [len] elements starting from [pos] an returns them.

toString.haxe_doc: Returns a displayable representation of the Array content.

unshift.haxe_doc: Adds the element [x] at the start of the array.

insert.haxe_doc: Inserts the element [x] at the position [pos]. All elements after [pos] are moved one index ahead.

remove.haxe_doc: Removes the first occurence of [x]. Returns false if [x] was not present. Elements are compared by using standard equality.

copy.haxe_doc: Returns a copy of the Array. The values are not copied, only the Array structure.

iterator.haxe_doc: Returns an iterator of the Array values.

class.haxe_doc: An Array is a storage for values. You can access it using indexes or with its API. On the server side, it's often better to use a [List] which is less memory and CPU consuming, unless you really need indexed access.

is.haxe_doc: Tells if a value v is of the type t.

string.haxe_doc: Convert any value to a String

int.haxe_doc: Convert a Float to an Int, rounded down.

parseInt.haxe_doc: Convert a String to an Int, parsing different possible representations. Returns [null] if could not be parsed.

parseFloat.haxe_doc: Convert a String to a Float, parsing different possible reprensations.

random.haxe_doc: Return a random integer between 0 included and x excluded.

class.haxe_doc: The Std class provides standard methods for manipulating basic types.

now.haxe_doc: Returns a Date representing the current local time.

fromTime.haxe_doc: Returns a Date from a timestamp [t] which is the number of milliseconds elapsed since 1st January 1970.

fromString.haxe_doc: Returns a Date from a formated string of one of the following formats : [YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss] or [YYYY-MM-DD] or [hh:mm:ss]. The first two formats are expressed in local time, the third in UTC Epoch.

getTime.haxe_doc: Returns the timestamp of the date. It's the number of milliseconds elapsed since 1st January 1970. It might only have a per-second precision depending on the platforms.

getHours.haxe_doc: Returns the hours value of the date (0-23 range).

getMinutes.haxe_doc: Returns the minutes value of the date (0-59 range).

getSeconds.haxe_doc: Returns the seconds of the date (0-59 range).

getFullYear.haxe_doc: Returns the full year of the date.

getMonth.haxe_doc: Returns the month of the date (0-11 range).

getDate.haxe_doc: Returns the day of the date (1-31 range).

getDay.haxe_doc: Returns the week day of the date (0-6 range).

toString.haxe_doc: Returns a string representation for the Date, by using the standard format [YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS]. See [DateTools.format] for other formating rules.

class.haxe_doc: The Date class is used for date manipulation. There is some extra functions available in the [DateTools] class.

urlEncode.haxe_doc: Encode an URL by using the standard format.

urlDecode.haxe_doc: Decode an URL using the standard format.

htmlEscape.haxe_doc: Escape HTML special characters of the string.

htmlUnescape.haxe_doc: Unescape HTML special characters of the string.

startsWith.haxe_doc: Tells if the string [s] starts with the string [start].

endsWith.haxe_doc: Tells if the string [s] ends with the string [end].

isSpace.haxe_doc: Tells if the character in the string [s] at position [pos] is a space.

ltrim.haxe_doc: Removes spaces at the left of the String [s].

rtrim.haxe_doc: Removes spaces at the right of the String [s].

trim.haxe_doc: Removes spaces at the beginning and the end of the String [s].

rpad.haxe_doc: Pad the string [s] by appending [c] at its right until it reach [l] characters.

lpad.haxe_doc: Pad the string [s] by appending [c] at its left until it reach [l] characters.

replace.haxe_doc: Replace all occurences of the string [sub] in the string [s] by the string [by].

hex.haxe_doc: Encode a number into a hexadecimal representation, with an optional number of zeros for left padding.

fastCodeAt.haxe_doc: Provides a fast native string charCodeAt access. Since the EOF value might vary depending on the platforms, always test with StringTools.isEOF. Only guaranteed to work if index in [0,s.length] range. Might not work with strings containing \0 char.

class.haxe_doc: The StringTools class contains some extra functionalities for [String] manipulation. It's stored in a different class in order to prevent the standard [String] of being bloated and thus increasing the size of each application using it.
